clinical_study.brief_title: Prospective Randomized Trial of Fruits or Nuts Eaten Between Regular Meals in Healthy Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Randomized Trial of Fruits or Nuts Eaten Between Regular Meals in Healthy Subjects

brief_summary.textblock: Recruitment of 28 subjects that will be randomized to consume fruit or nuts as snacks between regular meals for two months. Laboratory tests for cardiovascular risk factors, metabolic rate, liver steatosis and physical activity are investigated ahead of start of the study and at the end of the trial period och two months. Participants will be allowed to buy fruits or nuts on their own but to keep track (diaries) of the amount consumed. They will be reimbursed for the costs of the snacks.

primary_outcome.measure: amount of fat in the liver by magnetic resonance imaging
primary_outcome.description: exact measurement of fat in the liver by liver spectroscopy

secondary_outcome.description: Collection of markers for cardiovascular risk including glucose, insulin, lipoproteins etc. Analyses will be performed from blood samples.

arm_group.description: Participants are given +7kCal/kg body weight of fruit to be eaten as snack in between regular meals
Participants are given +7kCal/kg body weight of nuts to be eaten as snack in between regular meals

intervention.description: Randomization to extra fruit or nuts as snacks

intervention.other_name: Randomization to extra fruit or nuts as snacks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy subjects
Exclusion Criteria:
- significant diseases that can affect outcomes, mental disorders that can affect participation.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor, MD, Head of Internal Medicine

clinical_study.keyword: fruit, nuts, liver fat, insulin, glucose
Focus of the study is to compare the often given advice to eat fruit, containing large amount of glucose and fructose, with nuts that are more rich in fat.
